title-group.article-title: Angiotensin-converting enzyme I/D polymorphism is not associated with type 2 diabetes in a Chinese population

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Endocrinology, Linyin People’s Hospital, China
2Department of Epidemiology, Erasmus MC, Rotterdam, the Netherlands
3Department of Immunology and Rheumatology, Linyi Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine, China
5Department of Endocrinology, Medicine School of Shandong University, Jinan, China

author-notes.corresp: Jingling Zhang, Department of Endocrinology, Linyi People’s Hospital, 27# Jiefang Road, Linyi 276000, China. Email: jinglingzhang@126.com.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: A role for the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) gene has been suggested in the aetiology of type 2 diabetes (T2DM). However, results have been inconsistent. In this study, we performed a meta-analysis to further clarify the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM risk in a Chinese population.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: PubMed, EMBASE, CNKI and Wan Fang Data were searched for eligible studies. Pooled odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated using a fixed-effects model or random-effects model.

sec.title: Results::
sec.p: A total of 41 studies (4708 cases and 5368 controls) for the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM in a Chinese population were identified. The pooled ORs for the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM risk were not statistically significant under all genetic models (co-dominant model: DD vs. II: OR = 1.17, 95% CI 0.97–1.42 and ID vs. II: OR = 1.01, 95% CI 0.93–1.10; dominant model: OR = 1.06, 95% CI 0.94–1.19; multiplicative model: OR = 1.08, 95% CI 0.98–1.18). Although a marginally significant association was observed under a recessive model (OR = 1.17, 95% CI 1.00–1.36), robustness of this estimate could not be established under additional sensitivity analyses.

sec.title: Conclusions::
sec.p: The meta-analysis presented in this study indicated that ACE I/D polymorphism may not be associated with the risk of T2DM in the Chinese population.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Type 2 diabetes (T2DM), which is characterized by decreased production of insulin and/or insulin resistance, is now a serious disease worldwide.1 Since T2DM causes significant morbidity and mortality, it is of importance to identify and target risk factors involved in the development of T2DM. Besides conventional risk factors, genetic factors may also play key roles in the pathogenesis of T2DM. During the past decades, several candidate genes, including KCNJ11, PPARG, ENPP1, CAPN10 and TCF7L2, have been suggested to influence the risk of T2DM.

The angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), as one of the key components of the renin–angiotensin system (RAS), generates the vasoconstrictor angiotensin II and degrades the vasodilator kinine.2 It has been suggested that high levels of angiotensin II may also play important roles in glucose and insulin regulation and that angiontensin II may increase the risk of insulin resistance and diabetes.3 One of the most frequently described polymorphisms in the ACE gene is the insertion or deletion (I/D) polymorphism which consists of a 287-bp fragment in intron 16. The DD genotype is associated with higher levels of circulating ACE than ID and II genotypes.4 To date, many studies have assessed the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and risk of T2DM. However, the results have been conflicting. The discrepant findings might be due to differences in statistical power, the subjects’ enrollment, and genetic and environmental factors. Two recent meta-analyses indicated that the D allele of the ACE I/D polymorphism was significantly associated with the risk of T2DM in Europeans whereas only a marginally significant association was observed in East Asians.5,6 However, the marginally significant association in East Asians was not robust to different sensitivity analyses. In addition, these meta-analyses only included studies published in English, whereas numerous Chinese studies have been published in Chinese local journals. Therefore, in this study, we performed a meta-analysis of English and Chinese literature to clarify the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and the risk of T2DM in a Chinese population.

sec.title: Literature and search strategy
sec.p: PubMed, EMBASE, CNKI and Wan Fang Data were searched for eligible articles. The search strategy to identify all potential studies involved use of combinations of the following key words: (‘the angiotensin-1 converting enzyme gene’ or ‘ACE’) and (‘variant’ or ‘polymorphism’) and (‘type 2 diabetes’ or ‘T2DM’ or ‘noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus’ or ‘NIDDM’). The reference lists of retrieved reviews and articles were hand-searched. The publication language was restricted to English or Chinese. If more than one article was published using the same study population, only the study with largest sample size was selected. The literature search was updated on 30 September 2011.

sec.title: Inclusion criteria and data extraction
sec.p: Studies were included if they met the following inclusion criteria: (i) using a case–control or cohort design; (ii) evaluating the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM in the Chinese population; (iii) more than 50 cases; and (iv) providing sufficient data for the calculation of an odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI).

The following information was extracted from each study: (i) name of the first author; (ii) year of publication; (iii) region; (iv) sample size of cases and controls; (v) genotype distributions of cases and controls; and (vi) p value for the test of Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) in controls. Two authors independently assessed the articles for compliance with the inclusion criteria; disagreement was followed by discussion until consensus was reached.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM was assessed by calculating pooled ORs and 95% CIs under a co-dominant model, a dominant model, a recessive model, and a multiplicative model, respectively. The significance of the pooled ORs was determined by a Z test (p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant). A Q test was performed to evaluate whether the variation was due to heterogeneity or due to chance. A random-effects model (DerSimonian–Laird method7) or a fixed-effects model (Mantel–Haenszel method8) was used to calculate the pooled ORs in the presence (p ≤ 0.10) or absence (p > 0.10) of heterogeneity, respectively. Sensitivity analysis was performed by removing one study at a time to evaluate the stability of the results. Begg’s funnel plot, a scatter plot of effect against a measure of study size, was generated as a visual aid to detect bias or systematic heterogeneity.9 Publication bias was assessed by Egger’s test10 (p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant). Data analyses were performed using STATA version 11 (StataCorp LP, College Station, Texas, USA).

sec.title: Characteristics of the studies
sec.p: The literature search identified a total of 174 potentially relevant papers. Of these, 93 papers were excluded after reading the title or abstract because of obvious irrelevance to our study aim. In addition, 16 duplicated publications and four reviews were excluded. Therefore, 61 papers met the primary inclusion criteria. However, in 10 papers genotypes deviated from HWE in controls, and in another 10 papers there were fewer than 50 cases; these 20 studies were therefore excluded as well. Consequently, a total of 41 studies (4708 cases and 5368 controls)11-51 were included in the meta-analysis of the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM. The characteristics of the included studies are listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Characteristics of the studies included in the meta-analysis

fn.p: PHWE: P value for Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium test in controls.

sec.title: Meta-analysis results
sec.p: There was evidence of between-study heterogeneity under a homogeneous co-dominant model (DD vs. II: I2 = 51.1%, p for heterogeneity < 0.001), a dominant model (I2 = 42.3%, p for heterogeneity = 0.003), a recessive model (I2 = 38.5%, p for heterogeneity = 0.007), and a multiplicative model (I2 = 57.6%, p for heterogeneity < 0.001), respectively. Therefore, a random-effects model was used. No evidence of heterogeneity existed under a heterogeneous co-dominant model (I2 = 17.3%, p for heterogeneity = 0.171), therefore, in these analyses, a fix-effects model was used. The pooled ORs showed that there was no statistically significant association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM risk under all genetic models (co-dominant model: DD vs. II: OR = 1.17, 95% CI 0.97–1.42 and ID vs. II: OR = 1.01, 95% CI 0.93–1.10; dominant model: OR = 1.06, 95% CI 0.94–1.19; multiplicative model: OR = 1.08, 95% CI 0.98–1.18, Figure 1). A marginally significant association was observed under a recessive model (OR = 1.17, 95% CI 1.00–1.36) (Table 2). Sensitivity analyses were performed by excluding each study at a time (data not shown). Results from these analyses suggested that the marginally significant association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM risk was not robust.

caption.p: Forest plot of the meta-analysis of the association between ACE gene I/D polymorphism and type 2 diabetes under a multiplicative model (D vs. I).
Meta-analysis of association between ACE I/D polymorphism and risk of type 2 diabetes

fn.p: OR: odds ratio, CI: confidence interval.

sec.title: Potential publication bias
sec.p: No publication bias was detected for the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM risk under all genetic models (DD vs. II: p = 0.348, ID vs. II: p = 0.564, dominant model: p = 0.729, recessive model: p = 0.150, multiplicative model: p = 0.779).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present meta-analysis indicated that the D allele of the ACE I/D polymorphism may not be associated with an increased risk of T2DM in the Chinese population. In our opinion, the results of our study are credible since we had sufficient statistical power. In addition, the performed sensitivity analyses as well as the absence of publication bias further confirm that an association between ACE I/D polymorphism and T2DM may not be present. However, our results are conflicting with findings from two recent meta-analyses. In these studies, a statistically significant association was described between the ACE I/D polymorphism and the risk of T2DM among East Asians and among Europeans.5,6 However, the marginally significant association in East Asians was not robust to different sensitivity analyses. Moreover, we were able to include literature published in Chinese; therefore, the power of our study is larger in comparison with these two earlier published studies.

It is possible that the potential genetic effects on risk of complex diseases are different across various ethnic populations. In addition, the distribution of I/D polymorphism varies among different populations. In Europeans, the D allele frequency of this polymorphism52 is around 0.6 while in Chinese, the frequency of the D allele is estimated at 0.3.53 Therefore, the difference between the significant association among Europeans5,6 and the null results found among Chinese may not be surprising. However, it has also been suggested that the main effects of the individual loci might be too small to be observed and that loci may contribute to the complex diseases only by their interaction with other genes.54 Thus, the effect of the I/D polymorphism on T2DM among Chinese might involve other polymorphisms of RAS genes which play important roles in the same biological pathways.55

The ACE enzyme plays a key role in the production of angiotensin II and in the catabolism of bradykinin. It has been described that angiotensin II promotes the development of T2DM through a number of mechanisms, including interfering with insulin signalling, pro-inflammatory effects on tissue causing endothelial dysfunction, inhibiting adipocyte differentiation and causing beta-cell dysfunction via oxidative stress.56 It is possible that ACE I/D polymorphism affects the outcome through a linkage disequilibrium with other causative genes or polymorphisms. In contrast, pharmacokinetic studies have indicated a reduction of heart disease mortality, and a reduction in progression to T2DM among patients using ACE inhibitors.57

Several limitations of our study should be noted: first, the present meta-analysis was based primarily on unadjusted effect estimates and potential confounding factors could not be taken into account. Second, the effect of potential gene–environment interactions could not be addressed as well in this meta-analysis.

In conclusion, our study indicated that the D allele of the ACE I/D polymorphism may not be associated with T2DM risk in a Chinese population. Further studies with the consideration of gene–gene and gene–environment interactions should be conducted to further investigate this association.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
